meanings.definition: To make something a part of one's own being or consciousness.
meanings.sent1: Children often internalise the values of their parents.
meanings.sent2: She tried to internalise the importance of kindness in her daily life.
meanings.sent3: The teddy bear internalised the little girl's love and care.
meanings.sent4: His words seemed to internalise into her very soul.
meanings.sent5: The melody of the song internalised itself in his mind, playing on repeat.

meanings.definition: To incorporate or absorb something into one's own thoughts or beliefs.
meanings.sent1: Students need to internalise the information to succeed in the exam.
meanings.sent2: It is important to internalise feedback to improve one's performance.
meanings.sent3: The cat internalised the idea that the fish in the tank were its friends.
meanings.sent4: Her laughter seemed to internalise the joy of the entire room.
meanings.sent5: The scent of the flowers internalised a sense of peace and tranquility in the garden.
